title-group.article-title: Sialuria: Ninth Patient Described Has a Novel Mutation in GNE

contrib-group.aff: 13grid.414009.80000 0001 1282 788XCentre for Medical Genetics, Sydney Children’s Hospital, Randwick, NSW Australia
14grid.240562.7Queensland Lifespan Metabolic Medicine Service, Lady Cilento Children’s Hospital, South Brisbane, QLD Australia

fn.p: Communicated by: John H. Walter, MD FRCPCH

permissions.copyright-statement: © Society for the Study of Inborn Errors of Metabolism (SSIEM) 2018

abstract.p: Sialuria is a rare autosomal dominant inborn error of metabolism characterized by cytoplasmic accumulation and urinary excretion of gram quantities of free sialic acid due to failure of feedback inhibition of the rate-limiting enzyme in the sialic acid synthesis pathway, UDP-N-acetylglucosamine 2-epimerase/N-acetylmannosamine kinase (GNE/MNK). To date, eight cases had been published worldwide, all with heterozygous missense variants at the allosteric site, specifically at Arginine 294 (formerly 263) and Arginine 297 (formerly 266) of GNE. The described cases so far have rather homogeneous clinical features which include developmental delay, mildly coarse features, hepatomegaly and prolonged neonatal jaundice. The apparent rarity of this disorder is hypothesized to be due to the variable and sometimes transient nature of the clinical features and to the absence of routine testing for urinary sialic acids. Here we present the ninth case of sialuria diagnosed in a child investigated because of clinical signs and symptoms and furthermore describe a novel pathogenic variant in the associated gene, GNE.
